item.title: A Close Call
item.description: Beirut A Close Call A demonstrator walks past burning tires during protests on October 17 against Lebanon’s plan to tax calls made on WhatsApp, FaceTime and other apps. Hours later the government reversed course on the 20 cent daily fee. But in the midst of an economic crisis with the government declaring a state of “economic emergency” and public debts totaling 150 percent of gross domestic product, uncertainty remains.
item.dc:creator: Elizaveta Galkina

media:content.media:title: A Close Call
media:content.media:description: Beirut A Close Call A demonstrator walks past burning tires during protests on October 17 against Lebanon’s plan to tax calls made on WhatsApp, FaceTime and other apps. Hours later the government reversed course on the 20 cent daily fee. But in the midst of an economic crisis with the government declaring a state of “economic emergency” and public debts totaling 150 percent of gross domestic product, uncertainty remains.

item.title: Cry From the Heart
item.description: Port-au-Prince, Haiti Cry From the Heart A girl cries during her father’s funeral on October 16. The city has been paralyzed by anti-corruption protests for more than six weeks with mounting calls for President Jovenel Moise to resign. Tens of thousands of people have flooded the streets and 18 people have died in violent clashes. On top of a fuel shortage, Haitians are also struggling with a lack of access to safe water and food. Half of the country’s population lives below the poverty line.
item.dc:creator: Elizaveta Galkina

media:content.media:title: Cry From the Heart
media:content.media:description: Port-au-Prince, Haiti Cry From the Heart A girl cries during her father’s funeral on October 16. The city has been paralyzed by anti-corruption protests for more than six weeks with mounting calls for President Jovenel Moise to resign. Tens of thousands of people have flooded the streets and 18 people have died in violent clashes. On top of a fuel shortage, Haitians are also struggling with a lack of access to safe water and food. Half of the country’s population lives below the poverty line.

item.title: Broken Record
item.description: Vienna. Broken Record Kenya’s Eliud Kipchoge crosses the finish line on October 12 to become the first person to break the two-hour barrier for a marathon-distance run—a feat he compared to reaching the moon. The run, which was not an official marathon, was perfectly engineered and included a pace-setting laser projected from a car that was followed by pacesetters running in an aerodynamic “V” formation. Kipchoge’s final time was 1hr 59min 40.2sec.
item.dc:creator: Elizaveta Galkina

media:content.media:title: Broken Record
media:content.media:description: Vienna. Broken Record Kenya’s Eliud Kipchoge crosses the finish line on October 12 to become the first person to break the two-hour barrier for a marathon-distance run—a feat he compared to reaching the moon. The run, which was not an official marathon, was perfectly engineered and included a pace-setting laser projected from a car that was followed by pacesetters running in an aerodynamic “V” formation. Kipchoge’s final time was 1hr 59min 40.2sec.

item.title: The Queen’s Speech
item.description: London The Queen’s Speech Queen Elizabeth II sits alongside Prince Charles at the State Opening of Parliament on October 14. In her speech, which covered the government’s agenda for the coming year, the queen touched on Brexit and the bond between the four nations that make up the United Kingdom. She also mentioned climate change and how the U.K. will continue to “play a leading role in global affairs.”
item.dc:creator: Elizaveta Galkina

media:content.media:title: The Queen’s Speech
media:content.media:description: London The Queen’s Speech Queen Elizabeth II sits alongside Prince Charles at the State Opening of Parliament on October 14. In her speech, which covered the government’s agenda for the coming year, the queen touched on Brexit and the bond between the four nations that make up the United Kingdom. She also mentioned climate change and how the U.K. will continue to “play a leading role in global affairs.”

item.title: Drawing Fire
item.description: Quito, Ecuador Drawing Fire Demonstrators clash with riot police after thousands flooded the capital’s streets on October 9 to protest President Lenín Moreno’s order to end fuel subsidies. Indigenous protesters, who came from the country’s Amazon, led 11 days of demonstrations that caused Moreno to withdraw an austerity package and repeal subsidy cuts. In response, celebrations broke out across the city.
item.dc:creator: Elizaveta Galkina

media:content.media:title: Drawing Fire
media:content.media:description: Quito, Ecuador Drawing Fire Demonstrators clash with riot police after thousands flooded the capital’s streets on October 9 to protest President Lenín Moreno’s order to end fuel subsidies. Indigenous protesters, who came from the country’s Amazon, led 11 days of demonstrations that caused Moreno to withdraw an austerity package and repeal subsidy cuts. In response, celebrations broke out across the city.

item.title: Sent From Above
item.description: Dhaka, Bangladesh Sent From Above On October 8th, the final day of the Durga Puja festival, devotees submerge a clay idol of the Hindu goddess Durga. Each year, the days-long homage celebrates Durga with fasting, praying, processions and creative performances. It marks Durga’s defeat of the buffalo demon Mahishasura—a classic triumph of good over evil.
item.dc:creator: Elizaveta Galkina

media:content.media:title: Sent From Above
media:content.media:description: Dhaka, Bangladesh Sent From Above On October 8th, the final day of the Durga Puja festival, devotees submerge a clay idol of the Hindu goddess Durga. Each year, the days-long homage celebrates Durga with fasting, praying, processions and creative performances. It marks Durga’s defeat of the buffalo demon Mahishasura—a classic triumph of good over evil.

item.title: Holding Out Hope
item.description: Ras al-Ayn, Syria Holding Out Hope Syrian Kurds gather around a U.S. armoured vehicle near a U.S.-led coalition base during a demonstration against threats from Turkey on October 6th. The next day, U.S. forces, which had relied on the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces to help defeat ISIS, withdrew from northeastern Syria. Two days later, Turkey launched an offensive; within 48 hours, 23 Kurdish fighters had been killed.
item.dc:creator: Elizaveta Galkina

media:content.media:title: Holding Out Hope

Two days later, Turkey launched an offensive; within 48 hours, 23 Kurdish fighters had been killed.

item.title: Flying High
item.description: Stuttgart, Germany Flying High Team USA’s Simone Biles competes on the vault to win her fifth all-around world gymnastics title on October 10th. Biles’ unmatched skill and precision in landing some of the most difficult moves in gymnastics have seen a total of four moves named after the 22-year-old, who is now the most decorated gymnast in history.
item.dc:creator: Elizaveta Galkina

media:content.media:title: Flying High
media:content.media:description: Stuttgart, Germany Flying High Team USA’s Simone Biles competes on the vault to win her fifth all-around world gymnastics title on October 10th. Biles’ unmatched skill and precision in landing some of the most difficult moves in gymnastics have seen a total of four moves named after the 22-year-old, who is now the most decorated gymnast in history.

item.title: Choppy Waters
item.description: La Seu d’Urgell, Spain Choppy Waters Germany’s Florian Breuer competes during the 2019 ICF Canoe Slalom World Championships on September 26. The sport, which began in Switzerland in 1933 as a summer alternative to slalom skiing, involves navigating through a mix of upstream and downstream gates in whitewater rapids. The boats are smaller and lighter than canoe sprint boats in order to be maneuvered more quickly.
item.dc:creator: Elizaveta Galkina

media:content.media:title: Choppy Waters
media:content.media:description: La Seu d’Urgell, Spain Choppy Waters Germany’s Florian Breuer competes during the 2019 ICF Canoe Slalom World Championships on September 26. The sport, which began in Switzerland in 1933 as a summer alternative to slalom skiing, involves navigating through a mix of upstream and downstream gates in whitewater rapids. The boats are smaller and lighter than canoe sprint boats in order to be maneuvered more quickly.

item.title: Quiet Zone
item.description: Soura, Kashmir Quiet Zone Nearly two months after India revoked Kashmir’s semi-autonomous status, protesters shout anti-Indian and pro-freedom slogans during a torch protest on September 26. For weeks, residents have lived under a communications blackout: There is no mobile phone service or internet, making it difficult to contact loved ones or organize demonstrations. There are reports that thousands, including young boys, have been arrested.
item.dc:creator: Elizaveta Galkina

media:content.media:title: Quiet Zone
media:content.media:description: Soura, Kashmir Quiet Zone Nearly two months after India revoked Kashmir’s semi-autonomous status, protesters shout anti-Indian and pro-freedom slogans during a torch protest on September 26. For weeks, residents have lived under a communications blackout: There is no mobile phone service or internet, making it difficult to contact loved ones or organize demonstrations. There are reports that thousands, including young boys, have been arrested.

item.title: Standing Guard
item.description: Caracas, Venezuela Standing Guard National Guard members stand outside the National Assembly on September 24 as pro-government lawmakers return after a two-year boycott. President Nicolás Maduro said he wanted the politicians to “go to the fight” in the opposition-run legislature. That same day, President Donald Trump said the U.S. was watching the country “very closely,” and later in the week that “we have it under control.”
item.dc:creator: Elizaveta Galkina

media:content.media:title: Standing Guard
media:content.media:description: Caracas, Venezuela Standing Guard National Guard members stand outside the National Assembly on September 24 as pro-government lawmakers return after a two-year boycott. President Nicolás Maduro said he wanted the politicians to “go to the fight” in the opposition-run legislature. That same day, President Donald Trump said the U.S. was watching the country “very closely,” and later in the week that “we have it under control.”

item.title: Burn With Rage
item.description: Port-au-Prince, Haiti Burn With Rage Tires burn on city streets during a protest on September 25 against the country’s second fuel shortage this year. Due to an unreliable electricity grid, the country has depended on Venezuelan oil to power diesel generators. But sanctions, and huge government debt, have caused a fuel shortage that’s crippling hospitals, schools and businesses.
item.dc:creator: Elizaveta Galkina

media:content.media:title: Burn With Rage
media:content.media:description: Port-au-Prince, Haiti Burn With Rage Tires burn on city streets during a protest on September 25 against the country’s second fuel shortage this year. Due to an unreliable electricity grid, the country has depended on Venezuelan oil to power diesel generators. But sanctions, and huge government debt, have caused a fuel shortage that’s crippling hospitals, schools and businesses.

item.title: Hot in Here
item.description: Hot in Here Protesters take to the streets in the UK on September 20 as part of Global Climate Strikes, which were largely inspired by 16-year-old Swedish activist Greta Thunberg. Organizers say 4 million people on every continent—including scientists in Antarctica—took part. Independent researchers who documented the 2017 Women’s March are working to create their own estimates of how many people took action against climate change policies around the world.
item.dc:creator: Diane Rice

media:content.media:title: Hot in Here
media:content.media:description: Hot in Here Protesters take to the streets in the UK on September 20 as part of Global Climate Strikes, which were largely inspired by 16-year-old Swedish activist Greta Thunberg. Organizers say 4 million people on every continent—including scientists in Antarctica—took part. Independent researchers who documented the 2017 Women’s March are working to create their own estimates of how many people took action against climate change policies around the world.

item.title: Held Together
item.description: Held Together After becoming a sole parent of two earlier this year, when his wife died from the Ebola virus, 34-year-old Richard holds a mosquito net in his bedroom on September 17. The single father is himself one of nearly 1,000 Ebola survivors since an outbreak began in the country in August last year. More than 2,000 people have since died.
item.dc:creator: Diane Rice

media:content.media:title: Held Together
media:content.media:description: Held Together After becoming a sole parent of two earlier this year, when his wife died from the Ebola virus, 34-year-old Richard holds a mosquito net in his bedroom on September 17. The single father is himself one of nearly 1,000 Ebola survivors since an outbreak began in the country in August last year. More than 2,000 people have since died.

item.title: Game Plan
item.description: Game Plan Elizabeth Warren holds the biggest rally of her 2020 presidential run under the Washington Square Arch on September 16, after unveiling a sweeping anti-corruption plan. Many of the 20,000-strong crowd later waited for hours in a “selfie line” to meet Warren—tens of thousands of supporters have had their photo taken with the senator since she launched her campaign.
item.dc:creator: Diane Rice

media:content.media:title: Game Plan
media:content.media:description: Game Plan Elizabeth Warren holds the biggest rally of her 2020 presidential run under the Washington Square Arch on September 16, after unveiling a sweeping anti-corruption plan. Many of the 20,000-strong crowd later waited for hours in a “selfie line” to meet Warren—tens of thousands of supporters have had their photo taken with the senator since she launched her campaign.

item.title: Dress Rehearsal
item.description: Dress Rehearsal A popular holiday, Prinsjesdag, or Prince’s Day, is held on the third Tuesday of each September with the reigning monarch escorted through the city in a golden carriage (or glass carriage this year) to deliver a speech to the government. In preparation, members of the Cavalry honorary escort practice on the beach on September 16. There, the horses and riders are exposed to gunfire, cannon blows, music and smoke to ensure that they can handle the formal procession.
item.dc:creator: Diane Rice

media:content.media:title: Dress Rehearsal
media:content.media:description: Dress Rehearsal A popular holiday, Prinsjesdag, or Prince’s Day, is held on the third Tuesday of each September with the reigning monarch escorted through the city in a golden carriage (or glass carriage this year) to deliver a speech to the government. In preparation, members of the Cavalry honorary escort practice on the beach on September 16. There, the horses and riders are exposed to gunfire, cannon blows, music and smoke to ensure that they can handle the formal procession.

item.title: Showing the Colors
item.description: Spanish police estimated that about 600,000 people celebrated “La Diada,” the National Day of Catalonia on September 11. The annual festival, which traditionally draws big flag-waving crowds of supporters of indpendence for the reigon, marks the defeat of Catalan troops by King Phillip V of in 1714. This year’s attendance, however, was a decline from the roughly 1 million who turned out in 2018.
item.dc:creator: Diane Rice

The annual festival, which traditionally draws big flag-waving crowds of supporters of indpendence for the reigon, marks the defeat of Catalan troops by King Phillip V of in 1714. This year’s attendance, however, was a decline from the roughly 1 million who turned out in 2018.

item.title: Amazon Defender
item.description: Raoni Metuktire, chief of the Kayapo people of Brazil and an environmental activist, at a press conference held on September 6 ahead of the 2019 Climax Festival, a four day long series of talks, concerts and arts events emphasizing environmental responsibility. A group of Brazilian anthropologists and environmentalists have nominated Chief Raoni for the 2020 Nobel Peace Prize.
item.dc:creator: Diane Rice

media:content.media:title: Amazon Defender
media:content.media:description: Raoni Metuktire, chief of the Kayapo people of Brazil and an environmental activist, at a press conference held on September 6 ahead of the 2019 Climax Festival, a four day long series of talks, concerts and arts events emphasizing environmental responsibility. A group of Brazilian anthropologists and environmentalists have nominated Chief Raoni for the 2020 Nobel Peace Prize.

item.title: A Parent’s Pain
item.description: The father of Khaled al-Rabaee, a 14 year old Palestinian boy, grieves over his son’s lifeless body at al-Shifa hospital on September 6. Khaled was one of two teenagers shot and killed by fire from Israeli Defense Forces troops during clashes following a demonstration at the Israeli-Gaza border fence. About 6,000 Palestinians had participated in the weekly “March of Return” and hundreds were involved in the rioting that came afterward.
item.dc:creator: Diane Rice

media:content.media:title: A Parent’s Pain

About 6,000 Palestinians had participated in the weekly “March of Return” and hundreds were involved in the rioting that came afterward.

item.title: After the Storm
item.description: Marsh Harbour, Bahamas By the time Hurricane Dorian hit the Abaco Islands of the Bahamas it had reached category 5, the most severe classification, marked by driving rain and wind speeds of over 157 miles per hour. Dorian killed at least 50 people with over a thousand still missing and caused an estimated $6.5 billion worth of damages to the island nation. On September 5, a man surveyed the wreck of a boat driven ashore amid stripped trees on Great Abaco Island.
item.dc:creator: Diane Rice

media:content.media:title: After the Storm
media:content.media:description: Marsh Harbour, Bahamas By the time Hurricane Dorian hit the Abaco Islands of the Bahamas it had reached category 5, the most severe classification, marked by driving rain and wind speeds of over 157 miles per hour. Dorian killed at least 50 people with over a thousand still missing and caused an estimated $6.5 billion worth of damages to the island nation. On September 5, a man surveyed the wreck of a boat driven ashore amid stripped trees on Great Abaco Island.

item.title: Taranaki Volcano New Zealand
item.description: Rising 8,261 feet above sea level, the lonely mountain of Taranaki exercises a magnet-like pull over those fortunate enough to behold it. The area boasts more than 185 miles of trails, the longest and most challenging of which is the Around the Mountain Circuit that passes through a combination of lush forests and spectacular alpine peaks.
item.dc:creator: Diane Rice

media:content.media:title: Taranaki Volcano New Zealand
media:content.media:description: Rising 8,261 feet above sea level, the lonely mountain of Taranaki exercises a magnet-like pull over those fortunate enough to behold it. The area boasts more than 185 miles of trails, the longest and most challenging of which is the Around the Mountain Circuit that passes through a combination of lush forests and spectacular alpine peaks.

item.title: Walk to Remember
item.description: Some 200,000 Rohingya gather in the Kutupalong refugee camp on August 25 to mark the two year anniversary of a military crackdown in Myanmar. The violence prompted the mass exodus of more than 730,000 Rohingya who sought safety in Bangladesh. Earlier in the week, officials failed for a second time to repatriate a small number of refugees due to their ongoing concerns about having no path to citizenship in Myanmar
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Amodio

media:content.media:title: Walk to Remember
media:content.media:description: Some 200,000 Rohingya gather in the Kutupalong refugee camp on August 25 to mark the two year anniversary of a military crackdown in Myanmar. The violence prompted the mass exodus of more than 730,000 Rohingya who sought safety in Bangladesh. Earlier in the week, officials failed for a second time to repatriate a small number of refugees due to their ongoing concerns about having no path to citizenship in Myanmar

item.title: Seeing Red
item.description: A reveller is one of 22,000 people hit with tomatoes while celebrating the annual La Tomatina festival on August 28. The iconic fiesta begins each year when trucks tip more than 140 tons of tomatoes into the waiting crowd. Billed as the world’s largest food fight, it was inspired by a much smaller incident in 1945, though the details remain unclear. Tomatina was made an official festival in 1957 and has become a major draw for foreigners.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Amodio

media:content.media:title: Seeing Red
media:content.media:description: A reveller is one of 22,000 people hit with tomatoes while celebrating the annual La Tomatina festival on August 28. The iconic fiesta begins each year when trucks tip more than 140 tons of tomatoes into the waiting crowd. Billed as the world’s largest food fight, it was inspired by a much smaller incident in 1945, though the details remain unclear. Tomatina was made an official festival in 1957 and has become a major draw for foreigners.

item.title: Legacy of Grief
item.description: As Ukraine’s new parliament met for the first time on August 29, the influential weekly Dzerkalo Tyzhnia released a special edition dedicated to the mothers of 36 soldiers who died on the deadliest day of battle against Russian-backed separatists five years earlier. In May, comedian Volodymyr Zelensky won the presidential election and since then his party gained an outright majority—a first for any party in the country’s history.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Amodio

media:content.media:title: Legacy of Grief
media:content.media:description: As Ukraine’s new parliament met for the first time on August 29, the influential weekly Dzerkalo Tyzhnia released a special edition dedicated to the mothers of 36 soldiers who died on the deadliest day of battle against Russian-backed separatists five years earlier. In May, comedian Volodymyr Zelensky won the presidential election and since then his party gained an outright majority—a first for any party in the country’s history.

item.title: Heads Up
item.description: A man stands among the salvaged busts of 43 former U.S. presidents, including Woodrow Wilson(front), at the family farm of Howard Hankins on August 25. The busts, which are about 20 feet tall and weigh up to 18,000 pounds, were rescued by Hankins from Virginia’s closed Presidents Park after he was asked to destroy them. Tourists can now visit the decaying and crumbling heads.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Amodio

media:content.media:title: Heads Up
media:content.media:description: A man stands among the salvaged busts of 43 former U.S. presidents, including Woodrow Wilson(front), at the family farm of Howard Hankins on August 25. The busts, which are about 20 feet tall and weigh up to 18,000 pounds, were rescued by Hankins from Virginia’s closed Presidents Park after he was asked to destroy them. Tourists can now visit the decaying and crumbling heads.

item.title: Fuel to the Fire
item.description: A fire burns in part of Brazil’s Amazon on August 25 near Porto Velho. The Amazon, which is home to 1 million indigenous people in Brazil, has suffered from 40,300 fires so far this year, the fastest rate of burning since 2013, when record keeping began. Wildfires do occur during dry months, but illegal fires, which are started to deforest land for ranching or prepare already cleared land for next year’s harvest, are also common.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Amodio

media:content.media:title: Fuel to the Fire
media:content.media:description: A fire burns in part of Brazil’s Amazon on August 25 near Porto Velho. The Amazon, which is home to 1 million indigenous people in Brazil, has suffered from 40,300 fires so far this year, the fastest rate of burning since 2013, when record keeping began. Wildfires do occur during dry months, but illegal fires, which are started to deforest land for ranching or prepare already cleared land for next year’s harvest, are also common.

item.title: Strike Down
item.description: Syrian Civil Defence members carry a blanket-wrapped body at the site of a reported air strike that hit a clinic in Syria’s northern Idlib province on August 21. More than two dozen health care facilities in Idlib have been attacked since April. In that time, the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights has recorded more than 500 civilian deaths in the region, caused by air strikes and shelling from the Syrian regime and its ally Russia.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Amodio

media:content.media:title: Strike Down
media:content.media:description: Syrian Civil Defence members carry a blanket-wrapped body at the site of a reported air strike that hit a clinic in Syria’s northern Idlib province on August 21. More than two dozen health care facilities in Idlib have been attacked since April. In that time, the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights has recorded more than 500 civilian deaths in the region, caused by air strikes and shelling from the Syrian regime and its ally Russia.

item.title: On the Beat
item.description: Kicking off the Mariachi International Festival, 882 dancers spin and stomp their feet to set a new Guinness World Record for largest Mexican folk dance on August 24. Performing a choreographed routine for at least five minutes, the crowd smashed a previous record set in the same city by 457 music lovers in 2011. Two years later, 700 Mariachi musicians gathered there to break the record for most mariachis performing simultaneously.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Amodio

media:content.media:title: On the Beat
media:content.media:description: Kicking off the Mariachi International Festival, 882 dancers spin and stomp their feet to set a new Guinness World Record for largest Mexican folk dance on August 24. Performing a choreographed routine for at least five minutes, the crowd smashed a previous record set in the same city by 457 music lovers in 2011. Two years later, 700 Mariachi musicians gathered there to break the record for most mariachis performing simultaneously.

item.title: Cooling Off
item.description: Beachgoers take a dip at the end of a warm summer day in the Mediterranean Sea along the coast of Gaza City on August 16. In one of the world’s most dense cities, where residents have been locked in for years by a blockade, the sea provides respite and a sense of escape.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Amodio

media:content.media:title: Cooling Off
media:content.media:description: Beachgoers take a dip at the end of a warm summer day in the Mediterranean Sea along the coast of Gaza City on August 16. In one of the world’s most dense cities, where residents have been locked in for years by a blockade, the sea provides respite and a sense of escape.

item.title: At a Crossroads
item.description: Orthodox nuns, along with tens of thousands of Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate) believers, celebrate the 1,031st anniversary of the Christianization of Kievan Rus on July 27. Earlier this year, the Ukrainian Orthodox Church was granted independence from the Moscow Patriarchate, over protestations from Russia, and tens of thousands of its believers marked the same anniversary a day earlier.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Amodio

media:content.media:title: At a Crossroads
media:content.media:description: Orthodox nuns, along with tens of thousands of Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate) believers, celebrate the 1,031st anniversary of the Christianization of Kievan Rus on July 27. Earlier this year, the Ukrainian Orthodox Church was granted independence from the Moscow Patriarchate, over protestations from Russia, and tens of thousands of its believers marked the same anniversary a day earlier.

item.title: Searching for Change
item.description: A Palestinian garbage collector combs a landfill on July 29 in hopes of finding scraps he can sell to help him survive. With poverty exacerbated by undrinkable water, electricity outages and the 12-year-long Israeli blockade, some Palestinians desperate for income have resorted to scavenging through landfills. The UN estimates the unemployment rate­ in Gaza to be more than 50 percent—the highest in the world—and even higher for youth.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Amodio

media:content.media:title: Searching for Change
media:content.media:description: A Palestinian garbage collector combs a landfill on July 29 in hopes of finding scraps he can sell to help him survive. With poverty exacerbated by undrinkable water, electricity outages and the 12-year-long Israeli blockade, some Palestinians desperate for income have resorted to scavenging through landfills. The UN estimates the unemployment rate­ in Gaza to be more than 50 percent—the highest in the world—and even higher for youth.

item.title: All Fired Up
item.description: After weeks of pro-democracy rallies in Hong Kong, riot police fire tear gas at protesters on July 28. Residents initially took to the streets in June to march against a controversial bill that would have allowed extradition to mainland China. Hong Kong’s Chief Executive Carrie Lam has since declared the bill “dead,” but after violent clashes protesters are demanding Lam’s resignation and greater independence from Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Amodio

media:content.media:title: All Fired Up
media:content.media:description: After weeks of pro-democracy rallies in Hong Kong, riot police fire tear gas at protesters on July 28. Residents initially took to the streets in June to march against a controversial bill that would have allowed extradition to mainland China. Hong Kong’s Chief Executive Carrie Lam has since declared the bill “dead,” but after violent clashes protesters are demanding Lam’s resignation and greater independence from Beijing.

item.title: Breaking the Cycle
item.description: Egan Bernal, wearing the coveted yellow jersey, leads cyclists past the Arc de Triomphe during the last stage of the Tour de France on July 28. The 22-year-old, who beat out 175 riders over 2,162 miles, became the first Colombian to win cycling’s greatest race and the youngest winner in a century.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Amodio

media:content.media:title: Breaking the Cycle
media:content.media:description: Egan Bernal, wearing the coveted yellow jersey, leads cyclists past the Arc de Triomphe during the last stage of the Tour de France on July 28. The 22-year-old, who beat out 175 riders over 2,162 miles, became the first Colombian to win cycling’s greatest race and the youngest winner in a century.

item.title: Slow Burn
item.description: Protesters in Pakistan burn an effigy of Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi on August 16, as the United Nations Security Council held a rare meeting on the disputed region of Kashmir. India recently sparked a diplomatic row when it stripped the area of Kashmir it controls of autonomy by sending in troops, shutting down the internet and banning public gatherings
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Amodio

media:content.media:title: Slow Burn
media:content.media:description: Protesters in Pakistan burn an effigy of Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi on August 16, as the United Nations Security Council held a rare meeting on the disputed region of Kashmir. India recently sparked a diplomatic row when it stripped the area of Kashmir it controls of autonomy by sending in troops, shutting down the internet and banning public gatherings

item.title: High Notes
item.description: Alain Roche, a Swiss pianist and composer, plays his grand piano while suspended vertically in the air from a moving crane as dawn breaks on August 16, during the Jeux du Castrum multidisciplinary festival. Roche began his “Piano Vertical” project six years ago and continues to use the only piano in the world that is capable of playing vertically.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Amodio

media:content.media:title: High Notes
media:content.media:description: Alain Roche, a Swiss pianist and composer, plays his grand piano while suspended vertically in the air from a moving crane as dawn breaks on August 16, during the Jeux du Castrum multidisciplinary festival. Roche began his “Piano Vertical” project six years ago and continues to use the only piano in the world that is capable of playing vertically.

item.title: On The March
item.description: Hundreds of indigenous Brazilian women march toward the Ministry of Health on August 12 to protest against budget cuts and demand better health care. Indigenous women marched again the next day to denounce the “dismantling” of environmental and human rights policies by President Jair Bolsonaro’s government.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Amodio

media:content.media:title: On The March
media:content.media:description: Hundreds of indigenous Brazilian women march toward the Ministry of Health on August 12 to protest against budget cuts and demand better health care. Indigenous women marched again the next day to denounce the “dismantling” of environmental and human rights policies by President Jair Bolsonaro’s government.

item.title: Bowing Down
item.description: Muslim pilgrims perform prayers around the Kaaba, Islam’s holiest shrine, in Saudi Arabia’s holy city two days before the Hajj begins on August 9. The annual six-day pilgrimage is one of the five pillars of Islam and is a journey all Muslims must undertake, if they have the means, at least once in their lifetime.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Amodio

media:content.media:title: Bowing Down
media:content.media:description: Muslim pilgrims perform prayers around the Kaaba, Islam’s holiest shrine, in Saudi Arabia’s holy city two days before the Hajj begins on August 9. The annual six-day pilgrimage is one of the five pillars of Islam and is a journey all Muslims must undertake, if they have the means, at least once in their lifetime.

item.title: Taking the Plunge
item.description: For nearly seven decades, ambitious divers have launched themselves into rivers near Gjakova in Kosovo in an annual open-air high diving competition. In years past more than two dozen competitors have competed for the 500 euro ($556) prize money. On July 22 hundreds of spectators watched on as divers leaped off Ura e Shenjte, a 72-foot high bridge, and into the water below.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Amodio

media:content.media:title: Taking the Plunge
media:content.media:description: For nearly seven decades, ambitious divers have launched themselves into rivers near Gjakova in Kosovo in an annual open-air high diving competition. On July 22 hundreds of spectators watched on as divers leaped off Ura e Shenjte, a 72-foot high bridge, and into the water below.

item.title: Ole, Ole, Ole!
item.description: A football fan from Senegal cheered before Algeria and Senegal faced off in the 2019 Africa Cup of Nations at the Cairo International Stadium on July 19. Ultimately, Algeria’s “Desert Warriors” would defeat Senegal’s “Lions of Teranga” with a 1–0 victory, with the game’s only goal scored a mere two minutes into play. Algeria last won the trophy in 1990 and Senegal has yet to win.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Amodio

media:content.media:title: Ole, Ole, Ole!
media:content.media:description: A football fan from Senegal cheered before Algeria and Senegal faced off in the 2019 Africa Cup of Nations at the Cairo International Stadium on July 19. Ultimately, Algeria’s “Desert Warriors” would defeat Senegal’s “Lions of Teranga” with a 1–0 victory, with the game’s only goal scored a mere two minutes into play. Algeria last won the trophy in 1990 and Senegal has yet to win.

item.title: Too Hot to Handle
item.description: Two years after wildfires ravaged central Portugal killing more than 60 people and injuring dozens, the flames returned. This time some 1,700 firefighters and 400 vehicles were sent out to battle three blazes that raged across the heavily-wooded Castelo Branco region, over 100 miles north of Lisbon. As a firefighter looked at a wildfire at Amendoa in Macao on July 21, much of Europe was still sweltering through a heatwave.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Amodio

media:content.media:title: Too Hot to Handle
media:content.media:description: Two years after wildfires ravaged central Portugal killing more than 60 people and injuring dozens, the flames returned. As a firefighter looked at a wildfire at Amendoa in Macao on July 21, much of Europe was still sweltering through a heatwave.

item.title: World-Class Relief
item.description: On day three of a brutal heat wave—with temperatures remaining in the low 80s even at night and the heat index reaching as high as 110—some New Yorkers beat the heat in the refreshing spray of the Unisphere fountain at Flushing Meadows Corona Park on July 21.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Amodio

media:content.media:title: World-Class Relief
media:content.media:description: On day three of a brutal heat wave—with temperatures remaining in the low 80s even at night and the heat index reaching as high as 110—some New Yorkers beat the heat in the refreshing spray of the Unisphere fountain at Flushing Meadows Corona Park on July 21.

item.title: Hitting Back
item.description: U.S. Representative Ayanna Pressley speaks as (from left) Reps. Ilhan Omar, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Rashida Tlaib hold a press conference on July 15. The four progressive Democrats were responding to President Donald Trump’s tweet the day before in which he kicked off a cycle of outrage by wondering why they didn’t “go back and help fix the totally broken and crime infested places from which they came.”
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Amodio

media:content.media:title: Hitting Back
media:content.media:description: U.S. Representative Ayanna Pressley speaks as (from left) Reps. Ilhan Omar, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Rashida Tlaib hold a press conference on July 15. The four progressive Democrats were responding to President Donald Trump’s tweet the day before in which he kicked off a cycle of outrage by wondering why they didn’t “go back and help fix the totally broken and crime infested places from which they came.”

item.title: Time for a Change
item.description: Reggaeton singer Bad Bunny at a July 17 demonstration attended by thousands demanding Governor Ricardo Rossello’s resignation following the arrest of two of Rossello’s aides on corruption charges and the leak of hundreds of his texts that were sexist and homophobic and in which he joked about shooting San Juan’s mayor. Four days later, Rossello announced he would not seek reelection.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Amodio

media:content.media:title: Time for a Change
media:content.media:description: Reggaeton singer Bad Bunny at a July 17 demonstration attended by thousands demanding Governor Ricardo Rossello’s resignation following the arrest of two of Rossello’s aides on corruption charges and the leak of hundreds of his texts that were sexist and homophobic and in which he joked about shooting San Juan’s mayor. Four days later, Rossello announced he would not seek reelection.

item.title: In the Fire’s Mouth
item.description: Scavengers trying to snare offerings of food, money and other items thrown off the summit of Mount Bromo, an active volcano in Java on July 18. During the annual Yadnya Kasada festival members of the Tenggerese people of the area, joined by tourists, seek the gods’ blessings by throwing fruit, livestock, and rice into the volcano. Poor villagers supplement their incomes by climbing into the crater and catching what they can.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Amodio

media:content.media:title: In the Fire’s Mouth
media:content.media:description: Scavengers trying to snare offerings of food, money and other items thrown off the summit of Mount Bromo, an active volcano in Java on July 18. Poor villagers supplement their incomes by climbing into the crater and catching what they can.

item.title: After the Deluge
item.description: An Indian family took refuge on the roof of a hut in the Kamrup district of India’s Assam state on July 16 after torrential monsoons had washed away homes and caused landslides across South Asia. Authorities said millions of people were affected by the rains and flooding and 180 had been killed.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Amodio

media:content.media:title: After the Deluge
media:content.media:description: An Indian family took refuge on the roof of a hut in the Kamrup district of India’s Assam state on July 16 after torrential monsoons had washed away homes and caused landslides across South Asia. Authorities said millions of people were affected by the rains and flooding and 180 had been killed.

item.title: A Flying Leap
item.description: A heifer jumps over a pile of thrillseekers as part of this year’s San Fermin festival. After the daily running of the bulls through the streets of the city during the nine-day celebration, heifers are turned loose in Pamplona’s bullring. Though younger and smaller than their higher profile male counterparts, the fast, strong and sharp-horned female animals are just as dangerous.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Amodio

item.title: Cult of Personality
item.description: North Koreans bow before twin statues of Kim Il Sung (left) and Kim Jong Il, grandfather and father respectively of the country’s current dictator Kim Jong Un. The ceremony, at Pyongyang’s Grand Monument on Mansu Hill, was held to mark the 25th anniversary of Kim Il Sung’s death.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Amodio

media:content.media:title: Cult of Personality
media:content.media:description: North Koreans bow before twin statues of Kim Il Sung (left) and Kim Jong Il, grandfather and father respectively of the country’s current dictator Kim Jong Un. The ceremony, at Pyongyang’s Grand Monument on Mansu Hill, was held to mark the 25th anniversary of Kim Il Sung’s death.

item.title: Water Logged
item.description: A woman walks her bike near Lake Pontchartrain after Tropical Storm Barry came ashore on July 14. While the first hurricane of the Atlantic season was downgraded to a tropical storm after making landfall, it nevertheless caused widespread flooding and power outages and threatened additional flash floods.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Amodio

media:content.media:title: Water Logged
media:content.media:description: A woman walks her bike near Lake Pontchartrain after Tropical Storm Barry came ashore on July 14. item.title: No Peace
item.description: A Ukrainian soldier engages with Russian-backed separatists in the Donetsk region on July 13 as the five-year-old war in the east of the country drags on. Despite the Minsk Protocol, which attempted to effect a limited ceasefire, some 13,000 people have been killed and as many as 30,000 wounded since the conflict began.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Amodio

media:content.media:title: No Peace
media:content.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier engages with Russian-backed separatists in the Donetsk region on July 13 as the five-year-old war in the east of the country drags on. item.title: Turning Up the Heat
item.description: President Donald Trump, flanked by Vice President Mike Pence (right) and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, signed an executive order in the Oval Office on June 24 that placed new economic sanctions on Iran. The measure is designed to deny top Iranian political and military leaders access to financial resources.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Amodio
